[[File:Scully 05 Prince Charles Prince Charles & Vincent Scully.jpg|thumb|right|[[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]] accepts the 2005 Scully Prize from Professor [[Vincent Scully]] at the [[National Building Museum]].]] The '''Vincent Scully Prize''' was established in 1999 to recognize exemplary practice, scholarship or criticism in architecture, historic preservation and urban design. Created by the [[National Building Museum]] in Washington, D.C., the award first honored the distinguished Yale professor and namesake of the award, author and educator, [[Vincent Scully]].
The Museum’s website states that the Prize is awarded annually, however no award was made in 2003, 2004, 2015 or 2016. These omissions are not explained on the website.[https://www.nbm.org/about/awards/ “National Building Museum – Awards”] Retrieved 8 November 2018.
The 2014 Prize was presented to former talk show host [[Charlie Rose]]. The Museum website no longer lists Rose as a winner of the Prize.[https://www.nbm.org/about/awards/ “National Building Museum – Awards”] Retrieved 8 November 2018.
The National Building Museum awards two other annual prizes: the [[Honor Award]] for individuals and organizations who have made important contributions to the U.S.'s building heritage, and the [[Henry C. Turner Prize]] for Innovation in Construction Technology. ==Recipients== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Number !! Year !! Recipient |- | [[1999 in architecture|I.]] || 1999 || [[Vincent Scully]]http://www.yale.edu/opa/arc-ybc/v28.n14/story2.html |- | [[2000 in architecture|II.]] || 2000 || [[Jane Jacobs]] |- | [[2001 in architecture|III.]] || 2001 || [[Andres Duany]] and [[Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk]] |- | [[2002 in architecture|IV.]] || 2002 || [[Robert Venturi]] and [[Denise Scott Brown]] |- | [[2005 in architecture|V.]] || 2005 || His Highness the [[Aga Khan IV|Aga Khan]] established The [[Aga Khan Award for Architecture]] in 1977 |- | [[2005 in architecture|VI.]] || 2005 ||His Royal Highness [[Prince Charles]], the [[Prince of Wales]], for long-standing interest in the built environment and commitment to creating urban areas with human scale |- | [[2006 in architecture|VII.]] || 2006 ||[[Phyllis Lambert]], architect, educator, activist, philanthropist and founder of the Canadian Centre for Architecture and planning director for the Seagram Building |- | [[2007 in architecture|VIII.]] || 2007 ||[[Witold Rybczynski]], architecture critic, author and professor |- | [[2007 in architecture|IX.]] || 2007 || [[Richard Moe]], president of the [[National Trust for Historic Preservation]] |- | [[2008 in architecture|X.]] || 2008 ||[[Robert A. M. Stern]], Dean of the [[Yale School of Architecture|Yale University School of Architecture]] |- | [[2009 in architecture|XI.]] || 2009 || [[Christopher Alexander]], architect, architecture theorist, author and professor |- | [[2010 in architecture|XII.]] || 2010 || [[Adele Chatfield-Taylor]], president of the [[American Academy in Rome]]{{cite web|url=http://blog.classicist.org/?p=703|title=Adele Chatfield-Taylor to receive Vincent Scully Prize|author=Henrika Taylor|date=2010-09-24}} |- | [[2011 in architecture|XIII.]] || 2011 || [[William K. Reilly]], former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency{{cite news | title =Vincent Scully Prize: William K. Reilly| work = | publisher =National Building Museum | date =November 8, 2011 | url = http://www.nbm.org/programs-lectures/programs/2011-programs/november-2011/vincent-scully-prize.html| accessdate = 12 October 2011}} |- | [[2012 in architecture|XIV.]] || 2012 || [[Paul Goldberger]]{{cite web |url =http://www.nbm.org/about-us/press-room/press-releases/scully-prize-2012-press-release.html|title =National Building Museum Names Paul Goldberger as the Fourteenth Laureate of the Vincent Scully Prize| author= |date =August 29, 2012 |work = |publisher =National Building Museum |accessdate =11 April 2013}} |- | [[2013 in architecture|XV.]] || 2013 || [[Joshua David (High Line)|Joshua David]] and [[Robert Hammond (High Line)|Robert Hammond]], the co-founders of the Friends of the [[High Line]] in [[New York City]]{{cite web|title=Natl Bldg Museum Website|url=http://www.nbm.org/support-us/awards_honors/scully-prize/|accessdate=31 May 2014}} |- | [[2014 in architecture|XVI.]] || 2014 || [[Charlie Rose]], executive producer, executive editor, and host of [[Charlie Rose (TV series)|''Charlie Rose'']]{{cite web|title=Natl Bldg Museum Website|url=http://www.nbm.org/support-us/awards_honors/scully-prize/|accessdate=31 Oct 2014}} |- | [[2017 in architecture|XVII.]] || 2017 || [[Laurie Olin]], landscape architectChelsea Blahut, [http://www.architectmagazine.com/awards/laurie-olin-announced-as-the-17th-laureate-of-vincent-scully-prize_o "Laurie Olin Announced as the 17th Laureate of Vincent Scully Prize"], ''[[Architect (magazine)|Architect]]'', September 07, 2017. |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.nbm.org/support-us/awards_honors/scully-prize/ National Building Museum: Vincent Scully Award] [[Category:Architecture awards]] [[Category:Vincent Scully Prize winners]]

'''Visual arts of Chicago''' refers to [[paintings]], [[printmaking|prints]], [[illustrations]], [[Textile arts|textile art]], [[sculpture]], [[ceramic art|ceramics]] and other visual artworks produced in Chicago or by people with a connection to Chicago. Since [[World War II]], Chicago visual art has had a strong individualistic streak, little influenced by outside fashions. "One of the unique characteristics of Chicago," said [[Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts]] curator Bob Cozzolino, "is there's always been a very pronounced effort to not be derivative, to not follow the status quo."<ref name=Loviglio>Joann Loviglio, "Chicago Art Stars in Philly Exhibition", [[Chicago Sun-Times]], Wednesday, February 22, 2006, p. 49</ref> The Chicago art world has been described as having "a stubborn sense ... of tolerant pluralism."<ref name=Thodos>Diane Thodos, "Self-Portraits 2000", ''[[New Art Examiner]]'', May–June 2001, Vol. 28, no. 8-9, p. 92</ref> However, Chicago's art scene is "critically neglected."<ref name=Vine>Richard Vine, "[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1248/is_/ai_19385182 Where the Wild Things Were]", ''[[Art in America]]'', May 1997, pp. 98-111 {{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref> Critic Andrew Patner has said, "Chicago's commitment to figurative painting, dating back to the post-War period, has often put it at odds with New York critics and dealers."<ref name=Patner>Andrew Patner, "Chicago: Special Report: Contemporary Art", ''[[Art and Antiques Magazine]]'', Summer 1996, p. 53-55</ref> It is argued that Chicago art is rarely found in Chicago museums; some of the most remarkable Chicago artworks are found in other cities (such as the brilliantly warped epic drawings of [[Henry Darger]] at the [[American Folk Art Museum]] in [[New York City]], or [[Carlos Cortez|Carlos Cortez']] collection of early twentieth-century Chicago "Wobbly" ([[Industrial Workers of the World]]) woodcut prints, now in the [http://www.reuther.wayne.edu/taxonomy/term/12 Walter P. Reuther Library] at [[Wayne State University]] in [[Detroit]]).<ref name=Sherlock>Maureen P. Sherlock, "Missing/Inaction: 'Art in Chicago, 1945-95'", ''[[New Art Examiner]]'', February 1997, Volume 24, no. 5, pp. 23-27</ref>
==Early days: before the War== [[File:Davies-Elysian Fields, undated oil on canvas painting, The Phillips Collection (Washington, D. C.).jpg|thumb|right|Arthur B. Davies, ''Elysian Fields,'' undated, oil on canvas, [[The Phillips Collection]] (Washington, D. C.)]]
The [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]] was founded in 1879, from the remains of an earlier school founded in 1866 (thus the school predates the museum of the same name).<ref>Peter C. Marzio, "A Museum and a School: An Uneasy But Creative Union", ''Chicago History: The Magazine of the Chicago Historical Society'', Spring 1979, Vol. VIII, number 1, pp. 20-23; 44-52</ref> Early students and faculty were conservative and derivative in their tastes, imitating popular European models. [[Arthur B. Davies]], a former SAIC student and one of "[[Ashcan School|the Eight]]" was considered a disappointment for being a member of a radical group of urban modernists. In 1913, SAIC students held a protest with costumes and bonfires against the Chicago showing of the [[Armory Show]], a collection of the best new modern art; the newspapers described the students' activity as a riot.<ref name=Martinez>Andrew Martinez, "A Mixed Reception for Modernism: The 1913 Armory Show at the Art Institute of Chicago", The Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies, Vol. 19, no. 1, 1993, p. 31</ref>
Only a year later the African-American [[Realism (visual arts)|realist]] [[Archibald Motley|Archibald J. Motley]], graduated from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago; he kept his modern, jazz-influenced paintings secret for some years after.<ref>Elaine D. Woodall, "Looking Backward: Archibald J. Motley and the Art Institute of Chicago: 1914-1930", ''Chicago History: The Magazine of the Chicago Historical Society'', Spring 1979, Vol. VIII, number 1, pp. 53-57</ref>
[[File:Mary Agnes Yerkes, Blue Boat.jpg|thumb|right|''"Blue Boat"'' by Mary Agnes Yerkes, circa 1920, oil on canvas.]]
For many years the Art Institute of Chicago regularly held annual exhibits of local artists,<ref name=Martinez/> but these ended decades ago. [[Mary Agnes Yerkes]], (1886–1989), was an American Impressionist painter and one such exhibitor at AIC from 1912-1915. Born in Oak Park, she studied at the Chicago Academy of Fine Arts, where she also taught, and the at the currently named School of the Art Institute of Chicago.<ref>{{cite news |title= Miss Yerkes' Exhibit|newspaper= Oak Leaves|date= October 23, 1915| pages = 26–27}}</ref> She is noted for her plein-air painting while camping the American West and its National Parks.
==Interbellum: Chicago arts between the World Wars== The time period between the World Wars witnessed an outpouring of artistic creativity in Chicago, led by artists of the calibre of [[Stanislav Szukalski]], [[Todros Geller]]<ref name="occgeller">{{cite web|url=http://www.oakton.edu/museum/Geller.html|title=Todros Geller (1889-1949)|publisher=Oakton Community College|accessdate=21 December 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110322160221/http://www.oakton.edu/museum/Geller.html|archive-date=22 March 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and [[Albin Polasek]].
The Chicago art scene was not strictly an all-boys club however; [[Sr. Maria Stanisia]] was able to overcome the patriarchal attitudes both within early twentieth century [[Chicago]] and the hierarchy of the [[Roman Catholic Church]] to become acclaimed as one of the greatest painters in the field of [[religious art]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20040428164700/http://stmargaretofscotland.com/stations.htm Stations of Cross]</ref> Another [[Women Artists|woman artist]] [[Gertrude Abercrombie]] who like Stanisia attended the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]], sold her [[surrealist]] paintings in art fairs that took place near the [[Art Institute of Chicago]].<ref name=Warren>Warren, Lynne, ''Art in Chicago 1945-1995'', Thames & Hudson, 1996 {{ISBN|978-0-500-23728-1}}</ref>
==1940s== Early evidence of Chicago's unique style came with [[Ivan Albright]], with his "excruciatingly detailed surfaces depicting things in states of decay."<ref name=Holg>Garret Holg, "Art of the City: The Imagists -- and Beyond" ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', Sunday, March 22, 1998, Section B, pp. 1, 14</ref> [[Eldzier Cortor]] documented African-American life for the [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]].<ref name=Vine/> [[Vera Berdich]], an influential [[surrealist]] printmaker, taught many future [[Chicago Imagists]] at the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]].<ref name=Holg/>
==1950s: individuality, realism, surrealism== [[Claes Oldenburg]] was born in Sweden and only spent a few years in the 1950s in Chicago, but he sold his first works here, 5 pieces at the [[57th Street Art Fair]] for $25.<ref>David McCracken, "The Art Fair That's Been In the Picture the Longest", [[Chicago Tribune]], June 5th, 1987, page 3</ref>
Post-War art in Chicago was more figurative and less abstract than the [[New York City|New York]] fashion dictated, and was largely ignored by New York dealers and critics.<ref name=Patner/> Chicago artists rejected the abstract aesthetics of New York [[modernists]], preferring strong surrealism, "following their own vision,"<ref name=Loviglio/> and "savage political satire."<ref name=Sherlock/>
==1960s==
[[Claire Zeisler]], a fiber artist, switched from weaving to large, free-standing fiber sculptures which "redefined the art form".<ref name=Holg/>
===The Chicago Imagists=== In the late 1960s, a group of former students of the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]], many of whom had been mentored by teacher-artist [[Ray Yoshida]],<ref>Larry Finley, "Influential Figure in Chicago Art World: Teacher, Mentor to Artists in Imagism School of 1970s", [[Chicago Sun-Times]], Monday, January 19, 2009</ref> organized a series of exhibits at the [[Hyde Park Art Center]]. Their art was notable for its surrealism and cartoon-influenced grotesques.
Strictly speaking, they were three different groups: The earliest was the "Monster Roster", which included [[Cosmo Campoli]], [[Leon Golub]], [[Nancy Spero]], and [[Karl Wirsum]]; then the "Hairy Who", which included [[Art Green (artist)|Art Green]], [[Gladys Nilsson]], and [[Jim Nutt]]; and finally the [[Chicago Imagists]], which included [[Roger Brown (artist)|Roger Brown]], [[Ed Paschke]], and [[Barbara Rossi (artist)|Barbara Rossi]].<ref name=Vine/>
According to Imagist [[Ed Paschke]], the Imagists felt liberated by a lack of critical coverage. "There was a sense that no one much cared what we did here. We weren't going to get a whole lot of national attention. We could do what we wanted to do."<ref name=Holg/> After Paschke's death, in 2004, a New York critic infamously said that Paschke's "contribution to the art of his time was somewhat obscured by his distance from New York."<ref>Roberta Smith, "Ed Paschke, Painter, 65, Dies; Pop Artist With Dark Vision", New York Times, December 1, 2004</ref> At that same time, Chicago artists Tony Fitzpatrick and Wesley Kimler and art consultant Paul Klein stirred outrage when they reported that not a single Chicago museum had any of Paschke's work on display (a claim that was later disputed).<ref name=Foumberg>Jason Foumberg, "Art in Chicago 2000-2009: At Zeroes End", [[Newcity]], December 3, 2009, p. 4</ref>
In 1972 the Chicago Imagists were given recognition in a show at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago|Museum of Contemporary Art]].<ref>''Chicago Imagist Art'', Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, Illinois 1972</ref>
===The Chicago Surrealist Group=== Under the leadership of [[Penelope Rosemont|Penelope]] and [[Franklin Rosemont]], the [[Chicago Surrealist Group]] came together with both artistic and political ideals.<ref>{{cite book|first=Jack J.|last=Spector|title=Surrealist Art and Writing, 1919-1939: The Gold of Time|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-55311-3|year=1997|page=294}}</ref> In 1976 the group played a major role in organizing the World Surrealist Exhibition at the [[Gallery Black Swan]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.corpse.org/issue_10/critiques/postel.html |title="Women and the Surrealist Revolution: an interview with Penelope Rosemont" by Danny Postel, in 'Exquisite Corpse: A Journal of Letters and Life' |access-date=2014-08-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928020620/http://www.corpse.org/issue_10/critiques/postel.html |archive-date=2007-09-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==1970s==
Chicago produced several [[Photorealism|photorealists]], including [[Arne Besser]], and [[Richard Estes]]. Many photorealists were collected by Morton Neumann "against the grain of the prevailing critical thought at the time" (which espoused abstract expressionism), and exhibited at Chicago's [[Terra Museum of American Art]].<ref>"American Super Realism from the Morton G. Neumann Family Collection", Terra Museum of American Art, Evanston, Illinois 1983</ref>
==Chicago artists internationally==
Over the last few decades, many contemporary Chicago artists have become internationally successful. A persistent problem for the development of art scenes in Chicago has been the fact that, in the past, a large number of artists began in Chicago, but had to relocate elsewhere before gaining attention. [[Curator]] Robert Cozzolino sees this positively, stating that we must "recognize a powerful Chicago diaspora." Such artists include [[Claes Oldenburg]], [[Elizabeth Murray (artist)|Elizabeth Murray]], [[Richard Estes]], [[Robert Indiana]], [[Joan Mitchell]], [[Georgia O'Keeffe]], and many others.<ref>Robert Cozzolino, "Post:Correcting the Chicago Record", ''artblog'', February 3, 2006, http://fallonandrosof.blogspot.com/2006/02/correcting-chicago-record.html.</ref>
[[File:Ahava.jpg|left|thumb|'''Ahava''' (אהבה "love" in Hebrew), [[Weathering steel|Cor-ten steel]] sculpture by Robert Indiana (American), 1977, [[Israel Museum]], [[Jerusalem, Israel]]]]
Although no overarching theme or style characterizes Chicago's contemporary art, many contemporary critics contend that institutional support has favored Neo-Conceptual work almost to exclusion. Chicago art is nevertheless diverse and pluralistic, as is art in general. Contemporary Chicago artists continue to explore personal styles. Although abstraction has never been as strong in Chicago as in New York, there are noteworthy Chicago abstract artists, such as [[William Conger]], who paints brightly colored, sprightly designs, and [[Rodney Carswell]], whose work is more formal and cooler; and conceptual artists such as photographer [[Jeanne Dunning]] and installation artist [[Kay Rosen]].<ref>Garrett Holg, "City Focus Chicago: Industrious Evolution", ''[[ARTnews]]'', April 1998, p. 70</ref> Chicago's other notable contemporary artists are too numerous to name; but a few who would make any list are [[Kerry James Marshall]], [[Dan Peterman]], [[Gregg Bordowitz]], [[Julia Fish]], [[Wesley Kimler]], [[Tony Fitzpatrick (artist)|Tony Fitzpatrick]] and [[Iñigo Manglano-Ovalle]].
===Painters=== [[Robert Guinan]] paints psychologically penetrating portraits of bar patrons and jazz musicians which are very popular in France, but he is almost unknown in Chicago.<ref>John Golden, "Hunting Guinan: An Artist Renowned in France Finds Fame Elusive in His Native Land", [[New York Times]], Sunday, March 14, 2004</ref> Laurie Hogin continues the grotesque Chicago tradition with lush, Dutch-style portraits of cartoonishly savage animals.<ref>Alan G. Artner, "Hogin's Horrors: How a Gifted Representational Painter Became an Angry Philosopher-Activist", ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', Friday, February 28, 1997, Section 7, p. 41</ref> Ellen Lanyon's paintings show "fairy-tale gentleness and antiquarian whimsy."<ref name=Artner>Alan G. Artner, "Grabner Homes in on Subject Matter: Lanyon Exhibit Combines the Past with the Present, While Lowly Mixes Figures with Landscapes", [[Chicago Tribune]], Thursday, May 27, 1999, section 5, p. 2</ref> Riva Lehrer, herself disabled, paints intense, sympathetic, surreal portraits of disabled persons.<ref>[http://www.artcritical.com/thodos/DTLehrer.htm Diane Thodos reviews Riva Lehrer at the Chicago Cultural Center, 2004]</ref> Richard Loving paints luminous, spiritual abstractions.<ref name=Vine/> [[Tim Lowly]], who has mastered the difficult medium of [[egg tempera]], paints heartbreaking spiritual pictures of seemingly ill children.<ref name=Artner/> [[Audrey Niffenegger]] paints beautifully weird surreal images and writes acclaimed fiction as well.<ref name=Thodos/> Frank Piatek paints not-quite-abstracts of giant, writhing tube-forms.<ref name=Vine/> Judith Raphael paints pugnacious little girls posed like classical artworks.<ref name=Thodos/> [[Patrick Skoff]] leaves his paintings in public places for people to find and keep.<ref name="New City">New City Chicago Magazine - http://art.newcity.com/2009/07/28/on-the-hunt-patrick-skoff-wants-you-to-take-his-paintings/ 28 July 2009, "On The Hunt: Patrick Skoff Wants You to Take His Paintings"</ref>[[Matt Lamb]], a self-taught artist, creates luminous expressionist paintings with bold uses of color, whimsical figures and symbols, and unlikely combinations of mediums.<ref>Speer, Richard. Matt Lamb: the Art of Success. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons, 2005. Print,Gonzalez-Trejo, Pablo. "Matt Lamb - Self-Taught Irish American Artist." ArtSpace Virginia Miller Galleries - Miami Art Gallery - International and Latin American Art. Web. 21 June 2011. http://www.virginiamiller.com/artists/MattLamb/MattLamb.html</ref> Maria Tomasula paints exquisitely realistic, symbolic still-lives.<ref name=Thodos/> [[Wesley Kimler]] paints expressive, gestural, hybrid paintings that combine abstract and figurative elements in theatrical, sometimes grotesque and highly creative ways. John F. Miller taught for a few decades at the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago|SAIC]] and, during the bulk of that period, produced paintings and some drawings in an abstract style. Since the late 1990s, Miller has produced most of his work using compters and graphics software.<ref>Kevin Nance, "The Outsider With Loads of Talent, Rivaled Only by His Ego", ''Chicago Sun-Times'', 29 January 2006. Accessed on 23 February 2009 at http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1613293.html</ref> [[Mark Staff Brandl]] combines the influences of comic books, sign-painting and philosophy in talented paintings and installations which are accessible, intellectually demanding, and warily subversive.<ref>Judith Trepp, "Mark Staff Brandl at Tony Wuethrich", ''[[Art in America]], June/July 2005. Accessed on 23 February 2009 at http://www.markstaffbrandl.com/art_in_america/art_in_america.html</ref>
===Sculptors, textile art=== [[Cat Chow]] constructs dresses out of subversive materials.<ref>Kevin Cole, "Artist Spotlight: Cat Chow", ''[[Dialogue (magazine)|Dialogue]]'', May/June 2004, Vol. 27, no. 3, pp. 26-30</ref> [[Richard Hunt (sculptor)|Richard Hunt]] sculpts ruggedly abstract commentaries on social issues.<ref name=Vine/> [[Kerry James Marshall]] paints and sculpts multi-media works commenting on African-American life.<ref name=Holg/>
===Photography=== These same impulses also appeared in Chicago's lively [[Street photography]] scene, gaining notoriety through artists centered around the [[IIT Institute of Design|Institute of Design]] such as [[Harry Callahan (photographer)|Harry Callahan]], [[Aaron Siskind]], [[Leon Lewandowski]] as well as in the work of nanny-savant [[Vivian Maier]]. Ray K. Metzker and Barbara Crane studied at the Institute of Design in the 1950s. They spread the ideas of the Institute of Design teaching photography in the second half of the 20th century.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} Metzker was Philadelphia based and Crane was based in Chicago. [[Bob Thall]]'s beautiful, bleak photographs of Chicago-area architecture have also won much acclaim.<ref name=Vine/>
===Illustration, printmaking=== Contemporary [[illustrators]] include [[Jay Ryan (artist)|Jay Ryan]], whose hand-silkscreened posters have advertised many a rock band,<ref>Anders Smith Lindall, "Off the Wall: Jack Ryan's Whimsical Illustrations Put a Face on the Chicago Rock Scene", ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', Tuesday, December 20, 2005, p. 49</ref> and fantasist [[Scott Gustafson]].<ref>Cathy Fenner and Arnie Fenner, ''Spectrum 11: The Best in Contemporary Fantastic Art'', Underwood Books, Nevada City,</ref> [[Tony Fitzpatrick (artist)|Tony Fitzpatrick]] etches wild, detailed, tattoo-like pop images.<ref>Kim Carpenter, "Tony Fitzpatrick: Max and Gaby's Alphabet", ''[[Dialogue (magazine)|Dialogue]]'', January/February 2004, Vol. 27, no. 1, p. 13</ref>
===Public art=== [[File:Collage of public street art by Hebru Brantley in the Lincoln Square neighborhood of Chicago..jpg|thumb|Collage of Public art located near the CTA Western Brown Line stop in the Lincoln Square neighborhood of Chicago. Artist: Hebru Brantley]]
Chicago had a revival, dating to the 1960s, of public [[mural]] art, involving local artists and community members.<ref>Roger Eric Hoyt, "The Explosion of a Dormant Art Form: Chicago's Murals", ''Chicago History: The Magazine of the Chicago Historical Society'', Spring-Summer 1974, Vol. III, number 1, pp. 28-35</ref> [[Chicago Public Art Group]] is a non profit cultural organization in [[Chicago]] that organizes and promotes creation of community public art. Founded in 1971, several of its recent works have been large [[bricolage]] mosaics in city [[underpass]]es.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2012/06/29/your-chicago-ornate-underpass-murals/ |title=Your Chicago: Ornate Underpass Murals |publisher=[[CBS]]Chicago|date=2012-06-29 |accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref><ref name="timeoutchicago2">{{cite web|last=Weinberg|first=Lauren|url=http://www.timeoutchicago.com/arts-culture/art-design/65809/lake-shore-thrives |title=Lake Shore thrives - Art & Design |publisher=Time Out Chicago|date=2009-07-20|accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref>
Today, [[Jeff Zimmerman (artist)|Jeff Zimmerman]] paints photorealistic portrait murals, which can be found in various neighborhoods and restaurants in Chicago and Cincinnati.<ref>Richelle Kerns, "Jeff Zimmerman: A Chicago Muralist in the 'Hood", ''[[Dialogue (magazine)|Dialogue]]'', January/February 2004, Vol. 27, no. 1, pp. 50-55</ref>
==Irreverence, satire== [[File:Cowardly lion2.jpg|left|thumb|150px|W. W. Denslow's illustration of ''[[The Wonderful Wizard of Oz]]''.]]
Chicago has a strong tradition of satirical, even grotesque art and illustration. The early books of [[L. Frank Baum]] were illustrated with the strange work of [[William Wallace Denslow]].<ref>Russell P. Macfall, "The Baum Explosion",''Chicago History: The Magazine of the Chicago Historical Society'', Spring 1978, Vol. VII, number 1, pp. 59-62</ref> The Chicago tradition of political satire is seen in installation artist [[Öyvind Fahlström]], cartoonish artist [[Hy Roth]], and actual cartoonists [[Heather McAdams]] and [[Nicole Hollander]].<ref name=Sherlock/> Other Chicago cartoonists recognised by the art world include [[Lynda Barry]], [[Dan Clowes]], [[Jay Lynch]] and [[Chris Ware]] (whose work was shown at the 2002 [[Whitney Biennial]]).<ref>Christa Donner, ""Drawing the Line: Midwest Comics & Contemporary Art", ''[[Dialogue (magazine)|Dialogue]]'', Nov/Dec 2002, Volume 25, Number 4, pp. 27-28</ref> Significant comics artists from Chicago include [[Jessica Abel]],<ref>Joy Press, "The Further Adventures of Artbabe: Brooklyn Graphic Novelist Jessica Abel, Up From Underground", ''[[Village Voice]]'', Tuesday, March 14, 2006</ref> [[Herblock|"Herblock" (Herbert Block)]],<ref>Robert C. Harvey. "Herblock" in ''American National Biography Online April 2004 Update'' [http://www.anb.org/articles/17/17-01685.html online]</ref> animator [[Walt Disney]],<ref>[[Neal Gabler|Gabler, Neal]]. ''Walt Disney: The Triumph of American Imagination'' (2006). New York, NY. Random House. {{ISBN|978-0-679-43822-9}}</ref> adventure satirist [[Phil Foglio]],<ref>''Stanley and His Monster'' #2 (March 1993): Autobiographical page</ref> and goth cartoonist [[Jill Thompson]].<ref>Rockford Register Star staff. (November 7, 2005). "Meet a couple of comic book creators". ''[[The Rockford Register Star]]''. Pg. 1E</ref>
==Self-taught artists and Outsider Art== [[File:Brooklyn Museum - Xdx - Manierre Dawson - overall.jpg|right|thumb|Xdx by Manierre Dawson from ca. 1910]]
"Chicago emerged early on as an outpost for [[Outsider Art|outsider art]]," according to critic Andrew Patner.<ref name=Patner/>
[[Manierre Dawson]] was an early self-taught artist, who began painting abstracts in 1910. He was invited to display in the [[Armory Show]].<ref name=Holg/>
In the 1990s, a group of Chicago collectors, including Bob Roth, founder of the ''[[Chicago Reader]]'', and Ann Nathan and Judy Saslow, both of whom have opened acclaimed galleries, organized [[Intuit: The Center for Intuitive and Outsider Art]], which leads tours of Midwestern self-taught artists and has its own exhibition space.<ref name=Patner/>
Paul Waggoner, an eccentric himself, was an art dealer and champion of outsider art.<ref>Trevor Jenses, "Offbeat Gallery Owner", Chicago Tribune, Saturday, March 22, 2008, section 1, p. 17</ref>
Carl Hammer, an art dealer in Chicago, has handled much strange, figurative [[outsider art]], including the epic novel, illustrated with hermaphroditic girls traced from coloring books, of [[Henry Darger]], and the naive portraits of society ladies of [[Lee Godie]]. Hammer also represents [[Mr. Imagination (Gregory Warmack)|Mr. Imagination]], a self-taught bottlecap muralist<ref name=Patner/> Mr. Imagination, whose work is in several museums, also participated in the 2007 public art project, "[[Cool Globes: Hot Ideas for a Cooler Planet]]".<ref>"Cool Globes: Hot Ideas for a Cooler Planet: Guidebook", For Her Information Media, Chicago, Illinois 2007</ref>
==Troubles and controversies== In the 1980s, the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago|Museum of Contemporary Art]], along with the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] and Chicago's Department of Cultural Affairs, attempted to put on a show of contemporary Chicago art. Called "The Chicago Show", it was supposed to celebrate Chicago's artistic diversity. Embarrassingly, 84 of the 90 artists chosen by the 5-member blind jury were found to be white. The organizers published an apology in the exhibit catalogue and invited twenty minority artists who had not been juried in to participate. Half of the invited artists, angered by this condescension, refused and organized a counter-exhibit at the [[Chicago Cultural Center]].<ref name=Vine/>
On April 15, 1989, the same night that the [[Hyde Park Art Center]] celebrated its 50th anniversary, a devastating fire destroyed most of an entire block of important galleries and art spaces in the [[River North Gallery District, Near North Side, Chicago|River North gallery district]].<ref name=Patner/>
In spring of 1996, the Feigen, Inc. gallery's exhibit of [[Gregory Green (artist)|Gregory Green]]'s "10,000 Doses" and "Recipe for Making '[[LSD]]' in the Kitchen" was raided by the [[Chicago Police Department|Chicago police]], who confiscated and broke open the artworks. No drugs were found.<ref name=Patner/>
In 1996 the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago|Museum of Contemporary Art]], to get over the embarrassment of "The Chicago Show", attempted a survey of Chicago Art called "Art in Chicago: 1945-1995". It was criticized by the press as cramped, inadequate, and incomprehensive.<ref name=Vine/><ref name=Sherlock/> Its catalogue was judged a disappointment by Dennis Adrian, an art critic and participant, who called it "visually ... an atrocity of staggering proportions."<ref>Dennis Adrian, "This Map is Not to Scale", ''[[New Art Examiner]]'', February 1997, Volume 24, no. 5, pp. 20.</ref>
===Visual arts coverage=== In the last decade, all major print publications in Chicago have ceased seriously covering the visual arts . In 2009, the ''[[Chicago Reader]]'', an [[alternative newspaper|alternative]] weekly newspaper, reduced its formerly complete art listings of galleries and museums and regular art reviews by [[Fred Camper]] to "a smattering of listings and pictures".<ref name="autogenerated1">Jason Foumberg, "Art in Chicago 2000-2009: At Zeroes End", [[Newcity]], December 3, 2009, p. 5</ref> The ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', one of Chicago's two major newspapers, never had gallery or art listings and fired its sole dedicated fine arts reporter, [[Alan G. Artner]], in 2009.<ref name=Foumberg/> And the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', the other of Chicago's two major newspapers, has no gallery or art listings and no dedicated arts reporter, although [[Kevin Nance]] has covered some fine art issues along with movies and popular culture.
Additionally, The ''[[New Art Examiner]]'' (from Chicago) and ''[[Dialogue (magazine)|Dialogue]]'' magazine ([[Columbus, Ohio]]) reported on Chicago and midwestern arts communities until they both folded in 2002, though the ''[[New Art Examiner]]'' relaunched in 2015'<ref>{{cite web|title=New Art Examiner|url=http://www.newartexaminer.net}}</ref> ''[[Chicago Gallery News]]'', a glossy color magazine published three times a year, lists gallery shows but has no articles. ''[[Gallery Guide]]'' magazine publishes a Chicago/midwest edition which is similar.
However, smaller online and print publications have continued to cover the art scene in Chicago and have increased dramatically in number in recent years. Since 1988, [[NewCity Magazine|New City Magazine]] has covered the visual arts in Chicago, joined in the 1990s by [[Lumpen (magazine)|Lumpen Magazine]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}. [[Gapers Block]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Gapers Block|url=http://www.gapersblock.com|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> a Chicago-focused web publication established in 2003, added coverage with their arts and culture section. They were soon followed by Paul Klein's Art Letter<ref>{{cite web|title=Art Letter|url=http://www.artletter.com/info.html|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> in 2004 and the [[Bad at Sports|Bad At Sports]] podcast and blog in 2005. In 2008, print-based Proximity Magazine<ref>{{cite web|title=Proximity Magazine About|url=http://proximitymagazine.com/information/about/|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> was established, joined by two more print publications, Jettison Quarterly,<ref>{{cite web|title=Jettison Quarterly|url=http://jettisonquarterly.com/|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> and The School of the Art Institute's F News Magazine<ref>{{cite web|title=F News Magazine|url=http://fnewsmagazine.com/|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> in 2009. Also in 2009, Chicago Art Magazine broke off of Art Talk Chicago, part of the Chicago Tribune-sponsored blog network, to start their own independent online platform.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chicago Art Magazine - About|url=http://chicagoartmagazine.com/about/|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> Chicago Art Review, which ran from 2009-2011 and is currently in hiatus, began in 2009 as well.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chicago Art Review|url=http://www.Chicagoartreview.com|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> In 2010, Sixty Inches From Center was established and includes The Chicago Arts Archive, a web publication focusing on visual art in Chicago.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sixty Inches From Center|url=http://sixtyinchesfromcenter.org/|accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref>
Additionally, [http://www.chicagoartistsresource.org Chicago Artists Resource], launched by the Department of Cultural Affairs in 2005, provides articles on visual art in addition to providing resources and tools for Chicago artists.
Local artists' interests are represented by the [[Chicago Artists' Coalition]], a nonprofit advocacy organization, which has a monthly newsletter, the ''[[Chicago Artists' News]]''.
==See also== * [[Culture of Chicago]] * [[List of museums and cultural institutions in Chicago]] * [[Visual arts of the United States]] * [[Chicago Public Art Group]] * [[EXPO Chicago]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Chicago}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{orphan|date=March 2018}} [[Wall Hangings]] was an exhibition of textile [[fiber art]] at [[Museum of Modern Art]] from 25 February to 4 May 1969. It was planned in 1966 and toured 11 cities in 1968–1969<ref name="String, Felt & Thread" />.
==About== Wall Hangings Exhibition was curated by [[Mildred Constantine]] and [[Jack Lenor Larsen]] and featured 28 Artists from 8 countries<ref name="Exhibition Catalogue Book">{{cite book|last1=Constantine|first1=Mildred|last2=Lenor Laren|first2=Jack|title=Wall Hangins|date=1969|publisher=The Museum of Modern Art|location=New York}}</ref>. It was the first major art exhibition in [[fiber arts]] or textiles.<ref name="String, Felt & Thread">{{cite book|last1=Auther|first1=Elissa|title=String, felt, thread : the hierarchy of art and craft in American art|date=2010|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|location=Minneapolis|isbn=9780816656097|page=32-40}}</ref> Artworks were noted for their techniques, material, scale and three-dimensionality and were referenced both to their break from and use of tradition in those areas. The history of the artists in the show were directly attributed to the Austrian [[Wiener Werkstätte]] and the German [[Bauhaus]], though mention was made of other inspirations such as [[Pre-Columbian era|Pre-Columbian]] Peruvian [[Weaving|weavers]].<ref name="Exhibition Catalogue Book" />
==Ideology== The 19 December 1968 Press release by the [[Museum of Modern Art]] for the exhibition Wall Hangings states: "During the last 10 years, developments in weaving have caused us to revise our concepts of this craft and view the work within the context of twenty-first century art. The weavers from eight countries represented in this exhibition are not part of the fabric industry, but of the world of art. They have extended the formal possibilities of weaving, frequently using complex and unique techniques."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moma.org/momaorg/shared/pdfs/docs/press_archives/4163/releases/MOMA_1968_July-December_0095_135.pdf?2010|title=Press Release| accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref>
==Impact== The only national [[art world]] press was written by [[Louise Bourgeois]] for ''Craft Horizons'' and was negative and suggested that the work was not fine art.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Auther|first=Elissa|date=2008|title=Fiber Art and the Hierarchy of Art and Craft, 1960–80|url=|journal=The Journal of Modern Craft|volume=1.1|pages=19–20|via=Taylor and Francis}}</ref><ref name="String, Felt & Thread" /> As craft theorist Elissa Auther states in her 2009 book ''String Felt & Thread'': "Despite the awareness of the negative art world attitudes concerning media traditionally associated with the crafts, the strategy Constantine and Larsen adopted to assert fiber's art status was to introduce the new genre into the fine art world on the terms set by that world."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Auther|first1=Elissa|title=String, felt, thread : the hierarchy of art and craft in American art|date=2010|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|location=Minneapolis|isbn=9780816656097|pages=36}}</ref>
==Participating Artists== {{columns-list|colwidth=20em| * [[Magdalena Abakanowicz]] * [[Anni Albers|Ani Albers]] * [[Olga de Amaral]] * Evelyn Anselevicius * Thelma Becherer * [[Dolores Dembus Bittleman]] * [[Jagoda Buić]] * Zofia Butrymowicz * Barbara Falkowaska * Wilhelmina Fruytier * Elsi Giauque * [[Françoise Grossen]] * [[Sheila Hicks]] * Ewa Jaroszynska * Annemarie Klinger * Walter G.
